[3] "wake up ( weyk uhp ) phrase 1. (imperative; used to address one person) a. despiértate (informal) (singular) Wake up! Youll be late for school.¡Despiértate! Vas a llegar tarde a clase. b. despiértese (formal) (singular) Wake up, sir! I think this is your stop.¡Despiértese, señor! Creo que esta es su parada. c. despabílate (informal) (singular)"

Instructions: Using the provided web search results, write a comprehensive reply to the given query. Make sure to cite results using [[number](URL)] notation after the reference. If the provided search results refer to multiple subjects with the same name, write separate answers for each subject.
Query: Translate this sentence She didn't wake up on time into Spanish
Reply in Español

La traducción al español de la frase "She didn't wake up on time" es "Ella no se despertó a tiempo".

Puedes utilizar diferentes herramientas en línea para traducir esta frase, como Google Translate [[1](https://translate.google.co.id/?hl=en&tab=wT)] o Translate.com [[2](https://www.translate.com/english-spanish)]. También puedes encontrar la traducción de palabras y frases específicas en diccionarios en línea como SpanishDict [[3](https://www.spanishdict.com/translate/wake%20up)].

Instructions: Using the provided web search results, write a comprehensive reply to the given query. Make sure to cite results using [[number](URL)] notation after the reference. If the provided search results refer to multiple subjects with the same name, write separate answers for each subject.
Query: Translate this sentence She didn't wake up on time into Spanish.
Reply in Español

Hay varias opciones para traducir la frase "She didn't wake up on time" al español. Una opción podría ser "Ella no se despertó a tiempo" [[2](https://www.spanishdict.com/translate/she%20didn%27t%20wake%20up)]. Otra opción podría ser "Ella no despertó a tiempo" [[3](https://www.spanishdict.com/translate/wake%20up%20on%20time)]. Ambas opciones son gramaticalmente correctas y significan lo mismo. Además, se puede usar el servicio de traducción de Google [[1](https://translate.google.com/)] para obtener una traducción adicional de la frase.
Make a list of the 20 most common verbs in English

Here is a list of the 20 most common verbs in English in order of frequency:

1. be
2. have
3. do
4. say
5. get
6. make
7. go
8. know
9. take
10. see
11. come
12. think
13. look
14. want
15. give
16. use
17. find
18. tell
19. ask
20. work
Make a list of the 20 most common iregular verbs in English

Here are the 20 most common irregular verbs in English:

1. be
2. have
3. do
4. say
5. go
6. get
7. make
8. know
9. think
10. see
11. come
12. take
13. want
14. use
15. find
16. give
17. tell
18. work
19. call
20. try

Note: Some of the verbs on this list (e.g. be, have, do) are irregular in their conjugation but are also considered helping verbs or auxiliary verbs that are used with other verbs in a sentence.

1. Yesterday, I went to the gym and worked out for two hours.
2. My family and I went on a road trip last summer and visited several national parks.
3. After finishing her work, Sarah went to bed early to get a good night's sleep.
4. We went to the concert last night and had an amazing time.
5. When I was a child, I went to Disneyland with my parents and siblings.

1. Go after: To pursue or chase someone or something. Example: He went after the thief who stole his wallet.
2. Go ahead: To proceed or continue with something. Example: You can go ahead and start the meeting without me.
3. Go back: To return to a previous location or situation. Example: I need to go back home and get my phone charger.
4. Go out: To leave one's home or usual place to socialize or do something outside. Example: We're going out for dinner tonight.
5. Go over: To review or examine something in detail. Example: Let's go over the plan again to make sure we didn't miss anything.
Make a conversation between 2 people using phrasal verbs

Person 1: Hey, have you heard about the new cafe that just opened up?
Person 2: No, I haven't. What's it like?
Person 1: I haven't been there yet, but I'm planning to check it out this weekend. Do you want to go with me?
Person 2: Sure, let's go there together. What time are you thinking of heading out?
Person 1: Let's go in the morning. How about we meet up at 10 AM?
Person 2: Sounds good to me. I'll go ahead and put it on my calendar.
Person 1: Great! I'll pick you up and we can go there together.
Person 2: Sounds like a plan. I'm really looking forward to checking out the new cafe.
Make a reading using pharsal verbs

John is a student who is struggling to keep up with his coursework. He knows he needs to buckle down and focus, but he can't seem to get motivated. One day, he decides to reach out to his friend Emily, who always seems to be on top of things.

John: Hey Emily, I'm really behind on my assignments and I can't seem to catch up. Do you have any tips for me?

Emily: Sure John, have you tried breaking up your tasks into smaller pieces? It can be overwhelming to tackle everything at once.

John: That's a good idea, I'll give it a shot. But even when I sit down to work, I get distracted so easily.

Emily: I hear you. Maybe you should log off social media and put your phone away while you study. That way you won't be tempted to scroll through your feed or answer texts.

John: Yeah, I guess I should go all in and commit to my studies. But sometimes I feel like I'm in over my head.

Emily: Don't worry, John, you've got this. Just take it one step at a time and don't give up. I believe in you!

John: Thanks Emily, you're right. I need to knuckle down and stay focused if I want to succeed.

Emily: Absolutely, John. You can't coast through life, sometimes you need to put in the hard work and grind it out to achieve your goals.

John: You're so right. Thanks for your encouragement, Emily. I feel more motivated already.
